name: Faro
fun_fact: Fun fact: The cataplana isn't just a dish - it's a copper cooking vessel shaped like a clam that dates back to the Moorish era! Its tight seal locks in flavors, creating deeply aromatic stews that define Algarve cuisine.

hero_dishes.name: Cataplana de Marisco
hero_dishes.description: Seafood stew cooked in the signature copper cataplana vessel, featuring prawns, clams, mussels, and fish in aromatic broth with tomatoes, peppers, onions, garlic, and white wine
hero_dishes.origin_story: The cataplana is a symbol of the Algarve's rich culinary tapestry, tracing its origins to the Moorish era. The clam-shaped copper vessel's tight seal ensures all flavors and aromas are locked in. It has seamlessly integrated into the Algarve's gastronomic identity over centuries.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tasca do Ricky (ancestral Algarve recipes with standout seafood cataplana), Chefe Branco (classic Algarve comfort food with flavorful monkfish cataplana), Vila Adentro (18th-century azulejo factory with rare vegetarian cataplana option), Tertulia Algarvia (octopus cataplana). Most restaurants require minimum 2 people to order due to size.

hero_dishes.name: Arroz de Marisco
hero_dishes.description: Rich seafood rice dish somewhere between soup and risotto, loaded with prawns, clams, mussels, and crab in tomato-saffron broth
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Portuguese seafood rice that showcases the abundance of the Atlantic and Ria Formosa lagoon - a complete meal celebrating the sea
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tasca do Ricky (standout razor clam rice), Adega Nova (enormous seafood portions near train station)

hero_dishes.name: Grilled Fresh Fish
hero_dishes.description: Wild Atlantic fish like sea bass, golden bream, or sardines simply grilled with olive oil, sea salt, and lemon
hero_dishes.origin_story: Faro's prime location between Atlantic Ocean and Ria Formosa lagoon provides daily catches. Over 200km of coastline means fishing has provided food and income as long as the area has been settled.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tasca do Ricky (perfectly grilled fresh fish), Chefe Branco (classic grilled fish), Adega Nova (simple preparations, enormous portions). Often priced by weight.

signature_drinks.name: Vinho Verde
signature_drinks.description: Slightly sparkling 'green wine' from northern Portugal - light, crisp, refreshing white wine
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Perfect pairing for seafood, especially on sunny terraces overlooking the marina or Ria Formosa

signature_drinks.name: Algarve Regional Wines
signature_drinks.description: Local wines from the Algarve region pair beautifully with seafood cataplanas
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at lunch (1-3pm, main meal) or dinner (starting 7-8pm, locals dine 8-9pm)

signature_drinks.name: Ginjinha
signature_drinks.description: Portuguese sour cherry liqueur served in chocolate cups
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: As a digestif after seafood feasts
